clues.text: It truly was a whole New World in a 2012 TV movie called this title guy "and the Death Lamp"
In his memoirs this president of few words recalled being sworn in "by the light of a kerosene lamp"
Around 1807 Sir Humphry Davy lit up the first this 3-letter lamp using a 4-inch space between 2 charcoal sticks
The 513,654 bricks used to build this Boston landmark with one lamp or 2 were made & fired in kilns at nearby Medford
The opening verse of Rilke's poem "Archaic Torso of" this god compares said torso to a lamp

To shatter &
to halt a vehicle

To carry &
naked

An Alaskan seaport &
a fabled dwarflike creature

Illegal &
to provoke a response

One underling &
10 Jews praying
The Romans built Londinium on 2 low hills on the north bank of this river & built a bridge over it to the south
On the Isle of Anglesey in Wales, the Romans fought & wiped out these magical priests & destroyed their sacred groves
The Romans withdrew from Britain when the sack of Rome by these invaders led by Alaric required soldiers back home
Julius Caesar twice invaded in the 50s B.C. but the Roman invasion of Britain began in Earnest under this sickly emperor in 43 A.D.
In 306 A.D. while on a military campaign, Constantine was declared emperor by his army in Eboracum, now this city of the north
On "Severance" Helly & Mark toil away at this mysterious company
Season 8 of this visually challenged dating show debuted on Valentine's Day 2025
Aquaman on "Smallville", this big guy plays Jack Reacher on Prime Video
JFK famously dubbed this show that's still around today "the fifty-first state"
In 2018 this foreign-born sitcom star continued her reign as the highest-paid TV actress
She had a letter "on the breast of her gown, in fine red cloth, surrounded with... flourishes of gold thread"
In the first of a trilogy, this villain's "eye was rimmed with fire... yellow as a cat's, watchful & intent"
You may be team this character if you know he tells Bella, "The cold ones are traditionally our enemies"
This Hogwarts gamekeeper is described as having "hands the size of trash can lids"
This title guy in "A Tale of the Christ" is wrongly accused of a crime by his former pal Messala & is enslaved
This title of Grant Wood's most iconic painting alludes to the style of the farmhouse depicted in it
In 1944, at almost 84, she painted "The Old Checkered House in 1860", the year of her birth
This Impressionist chose a different kind of house-London's Houses of Parliament-for a series of paintings
Olson House in Maine is the home in the background in Andrew Wyeth's painting called her "World"
One of the lonely scenes painted by this American is 1925's "House by the Railroad", utterly devoid of people
Maintaining pace with Tommy Lee & Felicity of the acting world
The Mars rover committed felicide
In the fashion of a corvid aloft
Personally, everything is Hellenistic
Place to play baseball located within the untrimmed grass off the golf fairway
In an 1865 book this title character says, "The first thing I've got to do... is to grow to my right size again"
A baby animal is getting ready for bed in the rhymingly titled this animal this animal "Red Pajama"
A 1924 tale about 4 children hiding in this type of railway car has spawned more than 150 further titles
Body feature in common to Madeline, Anne of Green Gables & Caddie Woodlawn -hers "shone in the sunlight"
A clever mouse warns various woodland predators about this imaginary monster with "terrible teeth in his terrible jaws"
When you think of the Atlantic Coast Conference, you surely go to this state school near the East Bay; you can thank the Pac-12
Orange you glad you remembered Donovan McNabb, Donna Shalala & Ted Koppel are alums of this private N.Y. school
In 1846 the Kentucky legislature combined a medical school, a college & a law school as the university of this
John C. Calhoun's son-in-law left his fortune to South Carolina to create this university
"Pro Humanitate", or "For Humanity", is the motto of this school that began in its namesake N.C. town but is now in Winston-Salem

rounds.category: TRAINS & THE PEOPLE WHO LOVE THEM

clues.text: This train-loving president said, "I'm probably the most pro-rail guy in America. I've ridden over 1,300,000 miles"
In 1975 Jackie Kennedy Onassis stepped in to save this Beaux-Arts New York City landmark
Tiktoker Francis Bourgeois gained 3 million followers sharing this hobby, also the name of a Danny Boyle film
The company relaunching this train describes it as a "dream on wheels"; it first puffed east from Paris in 1883
This "commodore" didn't just love the sea; by 1873 he owned 4 railroads, including the New York Central

rounds.category: THE TITLE'S NOT IN THE LYRICS

clues.text: You'll hear "I wanna show you off" repeatedly in this Doja Cat hit, but not the title place
You'll hear the album title but not the song title in this Nirvana breakthrough smash; whatever, nevermind
A classic by The Who is titled "Baba O'riley", not "Teenage" this place, as the chorus might suggest
We can't repeat many of the words in her No. 1 hit "Hiss", but the title's OK
Am I just paranoid, or do you not know that the title of a 1994 hit by this popular punk trio is actually "Basket Case"?
This New York borough was actually named for but one woman, Catherine of Braganza
Westernmost of the prairie provinces, it was named for the wife of the Marquess of Lorne, a Canadian governor general
Maryland is named for Queen Henrietta Maria, the wife of this man for whom the Carolinas are named
This capital of South Australia was named for a consort of William IV
Yamoussoukro, a capital of this African nation, was named for a great-aunt of President Félix Houphouët-Boigny

rounds.text: Its creator imagined it as a place for young & old, offering "nostalgia of the past with exciting glimpses into the future"
